/bin/init.tc.py
values.title: Python scripts installation on remote machines

values.description:
Two tools will be available inside cloudsim-client-tools:

* ts_sniffer: Daemon that uses fping to measure the latency to a given host. The latency is published in redis.

* ts_controller: Controller daemon that tries to maintain a target latency. It uses redis for reading the target latency and the current latency (measured using ts_sniffer). There are different modes of operation: static {in/de}crement, dynamic {in/de}crement and PID.

   1. Static {in/de}crement: A fixed amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle.

   2.  Dynamic {in/de}crement: A variable amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle.

   3. PID: A variable amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle using a PID controller.
values.title: Tools for traffic shaping

summary.raw:
Two tools will be available inside cloudsim-client-tools:

* ts_sniffer: Daemon that uses fping to measure the latency to a given host. The latency is published in redis.

* ts_controller: Controller daemon that tries to maintain a target latency. It uses redis for reading the target latency and the current latency (measured using ts_sniffer). There are different modes of operation: static {in/de}crement, dynamic {in/de}crement and PID.

   1. Static {in/de}crement: A fixed amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle.

   2.  Dynamic {in/de}crement: A variable amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle.

   3. PID: A variable amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle using a PID controller.
summary.html:
Two tools will be available inside cloudsim-client-tools:

  • ts_sniffer: Daemon that uses fping to measure the latency to a given host. The latency is published in redis.

  • ts_controller: Controller daemon that tries to maintain a target latency. It uses redis for reading the target latency and the current latency (measured using ts_sniffer). There are different modes of operation: static {in/de}crement, dynamic {in/de}crement and PID.

  1. Static {in/de}crement: A fixed amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle.

  2. Dynamic {in/de}crement: A variable amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle.

  3. PID: A variable amount of latency is added or substracted to/from the current value during this controller cycle using a PID controller.

values.description:
1. Logfile with a descriptive header.
2. New option mode:
    * (-m new) Each start/stop cycle will generate a new file with a unique timestamp suffix.
    * (-m replace) Each start/stop cycle the logfile with be overwritten.
    * (-m resume) Each start/stop cycle the new data will be append to the logfile.
values.title: Bandwidth logging improvement

values.description:
Tool that accounts the TCP/UDP payload of all the packets.
It saves the stats into redis DB.
values.title: vrc_bytecounter

summary.raw:
Tool that accounts the TCP/UDP payload of all the packets.
It saves the stats into redis DB.
summary.html: Tool that accounts the TCP/UDP payload of all the packets. It saves the stats into redis DB.

values.description:
Tool that reads from Redis DB the current network usage stats and the uplink and downlink limits.
It periodically updates a log file with the network usage.
The activation of the netwatcher happens via ROS messages.
It also published the stats using ROS node.
The tool also disables the comms if the usage limit is reached.
An internal log shows the events of each log session.
values.title: Netwatcher

summary.raw:

It periodically updates a log file with the network usage.
The activation of the netwatcher happens via ROS messages.

The tool also disables the comms if the usage limit is reached.

The activation of the netwatcher happens via ROS messages. It also published the stats using ROS node. The tool also disables the comms if the usage limit is reached. values.description: Tool that reads from Redis DB the current network usage stats and the uplink and downlink limits. It periodically updates a log file with the network usage. The activation of the accounting starts via a vrc_score topic. It also published the stats using ROS topics. The tool also disables the comms if the usage limit is reached. An internal log shows the events of each log session.
values.title: Netwatcher ready for VRC

values.description:
Script for installing the private arenas and all the gazebo models

How to test the script?

1. Add your ssh public key into your bitbucket account (Manage_account->ssh_keys).
2. Run the script using your private key
3. Following the script instructions, source the new setup.sh at the end of the script.
4. Run gazebo or drcsim and check that the models and arenas work
values.title: set_vrc_private.sh

summary.raw:

summary.html:
Script for installing the private arenas and all the gazebo models

How to test the script?

  1. Add your ssh public key into your bitbucket account (Manage_account->ssh_keys).
  2. Run the script using your private key
  3. Following the script instructions, source the new setup.sh at the end of the script.
  4. Run gazebo or drcsim and check that the models and arenas work

values.title: Netwatcher tolerates an empty limit and a zero value (no limit)
exclude multicast packets from filter, cloudsim issue 131

values.description:
vrc_bytecounter over-counts bytes in certain circumstances, because it relying on the (incorrect) assumption that the Ethernet contribution to a packet is always only 14 bytes. For small packets, the hardware layer may add a trailer to pad out the frame.

vrc_bytecounter needs to use the IPv4 total length field, not the total captured bytes. From here, it can subtract off the IP header (and protocol headers as appropriate).
values.title: Patch to fix vrc_bytecounter

summary.raw:
vrc_bytecounter over-counts bytes in certain circumstances, because it relying on the (incorrect) assumption that the Ethernet contribution to a packet is always only 14 bytes. For small packets, the hardware layer may add a trailer to pad out the frame.

vrc_bytecounter needs to use the IPv4 total length field, not the total captured bytes. From here, it can subtract off the IP header (and protocol headers as appropriate).
summary.html:
vrc_bytecounter over-counts bytes in certain circumstances, because it relying on the (incorrect) assumption that the Ethernet contribution to a packet is always only 14 bytes. For small packets, the hardware layer may add a trailer to pad out the frame.

vrc_bytecounter needs to use the IPv4 total length field, not the total captured bytes. From here, it can subtract off the IP header (and protocol headers as appropriate).
